title: Preliminaries
Port-Hamiltonian Systems
text:
General port-Hamiltonian systems
The Hamiltonian (or total energy of the system) of a general port-Hamiltonian system is a continuously differentiable function \(H:\mathcal{X}\to\R\), for some domain \(\mathcal{X}\subseteq \R^n\). The Hamiltonian flow of energy is described by the gradient of the Hamiltonian \(H\), i.e. \[\begin{align*}
\frac{\partial H}{\partial x}(x) = \nabla H(x) = \left[\begin{matrix}
\frac{\partial H}{\partial x_1}\\
\vdots\\
\frac{\partial H}{\partial x_n}
\end{matrix}\right].
\end{align*}\]
By definition, port-Hamiltonian systems are (cyclo-)passive as a consequence of their system formulation. First, we define an input-state-output port-Hamiltonian system following Definition 6.1.1 in Van der Schaft (2000).

Definition: Input-state-output port-Hamiltonian system
An input-state-output port-Hamiltonian system with \(n\)-dimensional state space manifold \(\mathcal{X}\), input and output spaces \(U=Y=\R^m\), and Hamiltonian \(H:\mathcal{X}\to\R\), is given by \[\begin{align*}
\dot{x} &= [J(x) - R(x)]\nabla H(x) + g(x)u\\
y &= g^T(x) \nabla H(x)
\end{align*}\] where the \(n\times n\)-matrices \(J(x), R(x)\) satisfy \(J(x) = -J^T(x)\) and \(R(x) = R^T(x)\geq 0\).

By the properties of \(J(x)\) and \(R(x)\), it immediately follows that
\[\begin{align*}
\frac{d H}{dt}(x(t)) &= \frac{\partial^T H}{\partial x}(x(t))\dot{x}(t) = -\frac{\partial^T H}{\partial x}(x(t))R(x(t))\frac{\partial H}{\partial x}(x(t)) + y^T(t)u(t) \leq u^T(t)y(t),
\end{align*}\]
implying cyclo-passivity and passivity if \(H\geq 0\). An input-state-output pHS with non-linear resistive structure is given as
\[\begin{align*}
\dot{x} &= J(x)z - R(x, z) + g(x)u,\quad z = \nabla H(x),\\
y &= g^T(x) z
\end{align*}\]
where \(J(x) = -J^T(x)\), and the resistive mapping \(R(x,\cdot):\R^n\to\R^n\) satisfies
\[
z^TR(x,z)\geq 0,\quad\text{for all}\; z\in\R^n,\;x\in\mathcal{X}.
\]

Definition: pHS with feedthrough
An input-state-output port-Hamiltonian system with feedthrough terms is specified by an \(n\)-dimensional state space manifold \(\mathcal{X}\), input and output spaces \(U=Y=\R^m\), Hamiltonian \(H:\mathcal{X}\to\R\), and dynamics \[\begin{align*}
\dot{x} &= [J(x) - R(x)]\nabla H(x) + [G(x) - P(x)]u,\\
y &= [G(x) - P(x)]^T\nabla H(x) + [M(x) + S(x)]u,
\end{align*}\] where the matrices \(J(x), M(x), R(x), P(x), S(x)\) satisfy the skew-symmetry conditions \(J(x) = -J^T(x)\), \(M(x) = -M^T(x)\), and the nonnegativity condition
\[\begin{align*}
\left[\begin{matrix}
R(x) & P(x) \\
P^T(x) & S(x)
\end{matrix}\right]\geq 0,\quad x\in\mathcal{X}.
\end{align*}\]

title: Port-Hamiltonian Systems
text:
Properties of port-Hamiltonian systems

Definition: Casimir functions
A Casimir function for an input-state-output port-Hamiltonian system is any function \(C:\mathcal{X}\to\R\) satisfying
\[
\frac{\partial^TC}{\partial x}(x)[J(x) - R(x)] = 0,\quad x\in\mathcal{X}.
\]

A Casimir is a conserved quantity of the system for \(u=0\), independently of the Hamiltonian \(H\). In many cases of interest, the desired setpoint of a pHS is not equal to the minimum of the Hamiltonian function \(H\), but instead is a steady-state value corresponding to a nonzero constant input. This motivates the following Proposition by Van der Schaft (2000) and terminology of shifted passivity.

Shifted passivity
Consider an input-state-output pHS with feedthrough terms, together with a constant input \(\bar{u}\) with corresponding steady-state \(\bar{x}\) determined by \[
0 = [J(\bar{x}) - R(\bar{x})]\nabla H(\bar{x}) + [G(\bar{x}) - P(\bar{x})]\bar{u}.
\] Denote \[
\bar{y} = [G(\bar{x})+P(\bar{x})]^T\nabla H(\bar{x}) + [M(\bar{x}) + S(\bar{x})]\bar{u}.
\] Suppose we can find coordinates \(x\) in which the system matrices \(J(x), M(x), R(x), P(x), S(x), G(x)\) are all constant. Then the system can be rewritten as \[\begin{align*}
\dot{x} &= [J-R]\nabla \hat{H}_{\bar{x}}(x) + [G - P](u-\bar{u})\\
y - \bar{y} &= [G + P]^T\nabla\hat{H}_{\bar{x}}(x) + [M+S](u-\bar{u})
\end{align*}\] with respect to the shifted Hamiltonian defined as \[
\hat{H}_{\bar{x}}(x) := H(x) - \nabla^T H(\bar{x})(x-\bar{x}) - H(\bar{x}).
\] If \(H\) is convex in the coordinates \(x\), then \(\hat{H}_{\bar{x}}\) has a minimum at \(x=\bar{x}\) (with value \(0\)), and the pHS is passive with respect to the shifted supply rate \(s(u,y) = (u- \bar{u})^T(y - \bar{y})\), with storage function \(\hat{H}_{\bar{x}}\).

title: Port-Hamiltonian Systems
text:
Linear port-Hamiltonian systems
Linear port-Hamiltonian systems arise when the underlying Hamiltonian (or total energy of the system) is a quadratic function in the state, i.e. \[\begin{align*}
H(x) = \frac{1}{2}x^TQx.
\end{align*}\] for some state \(x\in\R^n\) with entries \(x_i\), \(i=1,\ldots, n\) and square matrix \(Q\in\R^{n\times n}\).

Definition: port-Hamiltonian system
Consider a time interval \(\mathbb{T}:=[0,T]\subset\mathbb{R}\), \(T>0\), a state space \(\mathcal{X}\subseteq\R^n\) and extended state space \(\mathcal{S}:=\T\times\mathcal{X}\). A port-Hamiltonian system (or pHS) is a system of ordinary differential equations of the form \[\begin{align*}
            \dot{x} &= (J-R)\nabla H(x) + Gu + Kd,\\
            y &= G^T\nabla H(x),\\
            z &= K^T\nabla H(x),
        \end{align*}\] with a Hamiltonian function \(\mathcal{H}(x):\mathcal{X}\to\R\), where \(x(t)\in\mathcal{X}\) is the state, \(u(t)\in\R^{m_1}, y(t)\in\R^{m_1}\), are the controllable input and output, \(d(t)\in\R^{m_2}, z(t)\in\R^{m_2}\) are the uncontrollable interaction ports. title: Home
text:
Getting Started

Prerequisites
To work with this repository, you’ll need:

Quarto - Download and install from https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/

Choose the installer for your operating system
Verify installation: quarto --version

Julia (Optional) - Required only if you want to execute Julia code blocks

Download from https://julialang.org/downloads/
Verify installation: julia --version




Setup
Clone this repository:
git clone git@github.com:bischoff-m/hamilton-sim-docs.git
cd hamilton-sim-docs
Quarto will automatically install any required Julia packages when rendering documents. Use the Julia REPL to add new packages as needed.


Preview
To preview the documentation locally:
# Start the preview server
quarto preview docs

# Or preview without watching for file changes
quarto preview docs --no-watch-inputs

# Or preview without opening a browser
quarto preview docs --no-browser
The preview server will start and display the local URL.


Build
To build static HTML files:
cd docs
quarto render
The generated site will be in the docs/_site directory.

title: Basics
text:
Linear form: \[
\dot{x} = Ax
\] where \(A\) is the state space matrix(?) and \(x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}\) always depends on time. In port-Hamiltonian systems: \[
\dot{x} = (J - R)Qx
\] where \(J \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n}\) is the interconnection matrix, \(R \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n}\) the dissipation matrix and \(Q \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times m}\) the linear part of the state. The more general non-linear description is \[
\dot{x} = (J(x) - R(x)) \frac{dH(x)}{dx}
\] where \(\nabla H(x) = \frac{dH}{dx}(x)\). For now, we keep \(J\) independent from \(x\). For specific systems it holds that \[
H(x) = \frac{1}{2} x^T Q x
\]
We are interested in description of dynamics, where we can influence the output. We then use the form \[
\dot{x} = Ax + Bu
\] where \(B\) is the input matrix. In port-Hamiltonian systems this translates to \[
\dot{x} = (J - R)Qx + Bu
\] \[
y = B^T Qx
\] where \(u\) is the input into and \(y\) is the output of the system. For now we are only interested in the state \(x\), but not the output. Later the output of one system will be the input of another system.

title: Basics
text:
Passivity
A passive system may consume and store energy, but is incapable of producing energy.
Exact definition: Celledoni, E., & Høiseth, E. H. (2017). Energy-Preserving and Passivity-Consistent Numerical Discretization of Port-Hamiltonian Systems (No. arXiv:1706.08621). arXiv. https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.1706.08621
